course_title: Management, Leadership & the Private & Disability Sectors

learning_outcomes.description: Explain the professional responsibilities, ethical obligations, and business skills needed to work in private practice and disability.
Engage critically and constructively with frameworks, legislation, philosophies of care and contemporary issues associated with disability to advocate across multiple settings.
Describe and interpret appropriate assessments across the ICF framework to design person and family-centred speech pathology intervention for people with a disability.
Explain the application of augmentative and alternative communication options for people with complex communication needs and their communication partners.
Advocate for and work in professional and interprofessional teams to support communication and swallowing for people with disabilities in the private sector.
Describe the value of supervision and mentoring in a private practice and disability.

assessments.due_date:
Week 10, Fri 1:00 pm

A detailed task description and marking criteria will be made available on the course Blackboard site.
assessments.task_description:
Working in groups with a private practice partner, students will develop a business plan advocating for the resource they are developing. This business plan will advocate for the purpose and efficacy of the resource within the private practice. Further details will be made available on the SPCH7211 Blackboard site.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: These assessment tasks are to be submitted via the course e-learning Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
After attending the Lived Experience of Disability Panel, students are required to submit one (1) video reflection. The panel discussion will inform this assessment and requires students to critically reflect on the perspectives shared by the panellists. In this assessment, students are expected to move beyond a descriptive summary of the panel and instead integrate insights from the discussion with relevant course concepts related to disability across the lifespan, communication, and professional speech pathology practice. Students will also reflect on how this learning will influence their future clinical reasoning and practice.

A detailed task description will be uploaded to the course Blackboard site.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The assessment task is to be submitted via the course e-learning Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
8/06/2026 1:00 pm

A detailed task description and marking criteria will be made available on the course Blackboard site. Each member of the group will receive the same mark on the completion of each activity.
assessments.category: Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Presentation, Product/ Design
assessments.task_description:
Working in groups with a private practice partner, students will develop a resource that has been determined by the private practice. This resource will be co-designed with the private practice partner to support professional conduct, life-long learning, and the practice of new graduate speech pathologists in this sector. The resource will be showcased in a recorded presentation. Further details will be made available on the SPCH7211 Blackboard site.

This assessment has three (3) different components:

Component 1: Private Practice Resource

  • Weight: 10%
  • Description: Students will provide a copy of their private practice resource and recorded presentation discussing the resource.


Component 2: Private Practice Resource Presentation:

  • Weight: 15%
  • Description: In a pre-recorded presentation, each group will share the co-design and development of the Component 1 Resource along with their private practice partner.


Component 3: Peer Evaluation (Budycheck)

  • Weight: 5%
  • Description: Students will complete a peer assessment on teamwork


These three components will be due during the first week of the exam block.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students will be required to submit their resource, audio-visual recording (presentation), and Buddycheck via the course eLearning Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This exam will be delivered in Inspera Assessment and will be completed on campus using your personal laptop.

The examination provides an opportunity to reflect on and synthesise the knowledge and skills developed across the semester and to apply this learning to authentic cases related to working with people with disability across the lifespan. Integration of knowledge and skills includes content from lectures, tutorials, workshops, and other relevant learning activities within the course. Please note that the disability-related content will be examined in the end-of-semester examination.

Further information, including details about the exam format, will be provided on the course Blackboard site.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Graduate Ready Modules: ‘Skills for graduates working alongside the NDIS in practice' & 'Being a health professional in Private Practice’

Given the impact of the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) on service provision and the increasing employment and practice education opportunities in Private Practice (PP), the School invested in a 12-month project to design a series of learning modules that prepare our allied health students for working in PP and the NDIS. This project had input from all disciplines within the school and was designed in collaboration with community stakeholders including industry professionals and consumers/lived experience experts – a process which ensured the modules are authentic, engaging, and practical. The modules are designed to prepare students to work in the Disability and Private Practice sectors upon graduation. Content from these modules will be assessed in the course end-of-semester exam.


Module 2: ‘Skills for graduates working alongside the NDIS in practice’

Learning objectives:

  • Display professional, self-management, and interprofessional practice skills as a health professional to support continued practice within the NDIS and the community more broadly.
  • Apply your professional clinical reasoning while working within the parameters of a disability-focused system such as the NDIS.
  • Understand the influences on and mechanisms by which you can advocate for clients, providers and professions in the NDIS.

 

Module 2: 'Being a health professional in Private Practice'

Learning objectives:

  • Consider the challenges and opportunities for a career in a private practice setting.
  • Understand the inherent professional and ethical responsibilities of working in a private practice setting.
  • Understand business needs and skills relevant to private practice.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 7 To Week 12(13 Apr - 24 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Online self-directed learning modules (self-directed learning)

A series of weekly online modules will provide information about working as a speech pathologist in the private practice sector and the holistic management of evidence-based practice for people with disability across the lifespan. The online modules will also cover Augmentative and Alternative Communication (AAC) for people with disability, including an overview of what AAC is and who benefits from it, AAC trial considerations and implementation, including the role of Key Word Sign (KWS).

The self-directed learning module content will cover a broad range of topics, including:

  • Working in the private sector as a speech pathologist
  • Marketing and business skills needed to work in private practice
  • Contemporary and evolving views of disability
  • The role of speech pathologists and interprofessional teams in supporting people with disability
  • Supporting people with lifelong conditions (e.g., cleft palate and hearing loss)
  • Supporting clients with complex communication and swallowing disabilities (both assessment and intervention).
  • Augmentative and Alternative Communication for people with disability.

Augmentative and Alternative Communication for people with disability.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 7 To Week 13(13 Apr - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Weekly on campus tutorials

Bi-weekly tutorials will be conducted from weeks 7-13 of semester and will incorporate inquiry-based learning and small group discussion to further explore private practice and speech pathology approaches to the holistic and evidence-based management of people with disability across the lifespan. Tutorials have been designed for experiential learning and therefore, students are expected to attend and actively participate in all tutorials. It is essential that students prepare for tutorials by completing the online self-paced learning modules and associated preparation activities. As students will be working in small groups during this learning activity, tutorials will not be recorded.


Note: Due to the geographical location of the presenters, two tutorial activities will be delivered online via Zoom. Further details will be provided in due course via the course e‑learning platform.

learning_activities.topic:
Supporting Clients with Craniofacial Abnormalities Workshop

This workshop will be facilitated by the Cleft Palate / Craniofacial Team, Speech Pathology Department, Queensland Children’s Hospital and will explore how speech pathologists support communication and feeding across the lifespan in people with craniofacial abnormalities. This workshop will be held on campus and will not be recorded.

Note. Due to the clinical availability of the guest presenters, this workshop is timetabled on a Friday outside normal tutorial hours.
learning_activities.topic_description: Supporting Clients with Craniofacial Abnormalities Workshop This workshop will be facilitated by the Cleft Palate / Craniofacial Team, Speech Pathology Department, Queensland Children’s Hospital and will explore how speech pathologists support communication and feeding across the lifespan in people with craniofacial abnormalities. This workshop will be held on campus and will not be recorded. Note. Due to the clinical availability of the guest presenters, this workshop is timetabled on a Friday outside normal tutorial hours.

learning_activities.topic:
Lived Experience of Disability Lecture

In this learning activity, you will explore disability through direct engagement with a person with disability and their treating professionals. The session is designed to centre lived experience and professional perspectives, providing insight into how disability is experienced, supported, and understood in everyday life and clinical practice.

By attending this activity, you will have the opportunity to listen to personal stories, learn about the roles of different health professionals, and reflect on how collaboration, communication, and respect underpin person‑centred care. This interactive panel-lecture also provides a safe and respectful space for you to ask questions and engage in meaningful dialogue with the panellists.

Note*: Due to the nature of this activity and the availability of the panellists, it will be scheduled on a Tuesday, outside typical tutorial hours.

learning_activities.topic:
Final lecture

The final lecture (Week 13) will review the course as a whole and discuss end of semester assessment. Attendance in person is strongly encouraged.
